ğŸ“– Tá»•ng quan

LiÃªn tá»¥c nhÆ°ng khÃ´ng liÃªn tá»¥c Ä‘á»u - Nguá»“n: Wikimedia Commons

ğŸ¯ Equivalent Metrics

1. Definition vÃ  Characterizations

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Equivalent Metrics):
Hai metrics dâ‚, dâ‚‚ trÃªn X equivalent (hay topologically equivalent) náº¿u chÃºng induce cÃ¹ng topology:

\[\tau_{d_1} = \tau_{d_2}\]

Notation: dâ‚ ~ dâ‚‚.

Trá»±c giÃ¡c: Same open sets, same convergent sequences, same continuous functions.

Proposition (Characterization báº±ng Identity Map):
dâ‚ ~ dâ‚‚ âŸº id: (X, dâ‚) â†’ (X, dâ‚‚) homeomorphism.

Proof:
id homeomorphism âŸº id, idâ»Â¹ continuous âŸº Ï„dâ‚ = Ï„dâ‚‚. âœ“

Proposition (Characterization báº±ng Convergence):
dâ‚ ~ dâ‚‚ âŸº má»i sequence:

\[x_n \xrightarrow{d_1} x \iff x_n \xrightarrow{d_2} x\]

Proof (â‡’):
Ï„dâ‚ = Ï„dâ‚‚ â‡’ same closed sets â‡’ same convergent sequences. âœ“

Proof (â‡):
Convergence characterizes closed sets (first countable) â‡’ same closed sets â‡’ same topology. âœ“

Proposition (Characterization báº±ng Open Balls):
dâ‚ ~ dâ‚‚ âŸº âˆ€x, râ‚ > 0: âˆƒrâ‚‚ > 0: Bdâ‚‚(x, râ‚‚) âŠ† Bdâ‚(x, râ‚)
vÃ  ngÆ°á»£c láº¡i.

Proof: Basis cho topology. âœ“

Practical: Check balls contain each other.

2. Examples trÃªn â„â¿

Theorem (Equivalence trÃªn â„â¿):
TrÃªn â„â¿, cÃ¡c metrics sau equivalent:

(1) Euclidean: dâ‚‚(x,y) = (Î£(xáµ¢ - yáµ¢)Â²)^(1/2)

(2) Manhattan: dâ‚(x,y) = Î£ xáµ¢ - yáµ¢
(3) Maximum: dâˆ(x,y) = maxáµ¢ xáµ¢ - yáµ¢

Proof:
Chá»©ng minh dâˆ â‰¤ dâ‚‚ â‰¤ dâ‚ â‰¤ nÂ·dâˆ.

Step 1: dâˆ â‰¤ dâ‚‚.
maxáµ¢ |xáµ¢ - yáµ¢| â‰¤ (Î£(xáµ¢ - yáµ¢)Â²)^(1/2). âœ“

Step 2: dâ‚‚ â‰¤ dâ‚.
(Î£(xáµ¢ - yáµ¢)Â²)^(1/2) â‰¤ Î£|xáµ¢ - yáµ¢| (drop squares). âœ“

Step 3: dâ‚ â‰¤ nÂ·dâˆ.
Î£|xáµ¢ - yáµ¢| â‰¤ n Â· maxáµ¢ |xáµ¢ - yáµ¢|. âœ“

Conclusion: dâˆ â‰¤ dâ‚‚ â‰¤ dâ‚ â‰¤ nÂ·dâˆ â‡’ equivalent. âœ“

Remark: Constants depend on n, nhÆ°ng equivalence holds.

Corollary:
Má»i Láµ– metric trÃªn â„â¿ (p â‰¥ 1) equivalent.

Proof: Similar inequalities.

Consequence: Topology cá»§a â„â¿ well-defined (independent cá»§a choice metric).

3. Examples NOT Equivalent

Example 1: Discrete vs Euclidean trÃªn â„

Discrete metric: \(d_{\text{disc}}(x,y) = \begin{cases} 0 & x = y \\ 1 & x \neq y \end{cases}\)

Claim: d_disc â‰ d_Euclidean trÃªn â„.

Proof:
{x} open trong (â„, d_disc) nhÆ°ng khÃ´ng open trong (â„, d_Euclidean). âœ“

Lesson: Discrete metric induces discrete topology, very different!

Example 2: Different Function Space Metrics

TrÃªn C([0,1]):

(1) Uniform metric: dâˆ(f,g) = sup f(x) - g(x)
(2) LÂ¹ metric: dâ‚(f,g) = âˆ« f(x) - g(x) dx

Claim: dâˆ â‰ dâ‚.

Proof:
Sequence fâ‚™(x) = xâ¿:

  • dâ‚(fâ‚™, 0) = âˆ«â‚€Â¹ xâ¿ dx = 1/(n+1) â†’ 0 (converge trong LÂ¹)
  • dâˆ(fâ‚™, 0) = 1 âˆ€n (khÃ´ng converge uniformly)

Váº­y convergence khÃ¡c â‡’ topology khÃ¡c. âœ“

Lesson: Metrics trÃªn function spaces very sensitive!

4. Strongly Equivalent Metrics

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Strongly Equivalent):
dâ‚, dâ‚‚ strongly equivalent (hay uniformly equivalent) náº¿u âˆƒcâ‚, câ‚‚ > 0:

\[c_1 d_1(x,y) \leq d_2(x,y) \leq c_2 d_1(x,y) \quad \forall x,y\]

Notation: dâ‚ â‰ˆ dâ‚‚.

Trá»±c giÃ¡c: Metrics differ by constants only.

Theorem:
Strongly equivalent â‡’ equivalent.

Proof: Inequalities â‡’ open balls contain each other. âœ“

Converse sai: Equivalent â‰  strongly equivalent.

Example: d(x,y) = x - y vÃ  dâ€™(x,y) = min( x - y , 1) trÃªn â„ equivalent nhÆ°ng khÃ´ng strongly equivalent.

Theorem:
dâ‚ â‰ˆ dâ‚‚ â‡’ same Cauchy sequences, same completeness.

Proof: Inequalities preserve Cauchy property. âœ“

Contrast: Equivalent metrics cÃ³ thá»ƒ have different completeness!

Example: d vÃ  dâ€™ = min(d, 1):

  • d ~ dâ€™ (same topology)
  • d unbounded, dâ€™ bounded
  • Completeness cÃ³ thá»ƒ differ

ğŸ”„ Uniform Continuity

1. Definition vÃ  Motivation

Nháº¯c láº¡i (Continuity):
f: (X, d_X) â†’ (Y, d_Y) continuous táº¡i x:

\[\forall \varepsilon > 0: \exists \delta > 0: d_X(x, x') < \delta \Rightarrow d_Y(f(x), f(x')) < \varepsilon\]

ChÃº Ã½: Î´ phá»¥ thuá»™c x vÃ  Îµ.

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Uniform Continuity):
f uniformly continuous náº¿u:

\[\forall \varepsilon > 0: \exists \delta > 0: \forall x, x' \in X: d_X(x, x') < \delta \Rightarrow d_Y(f(x), f(x')) < \varepsilon\]

KhÃ¡c biá»‡t: Î´ chá»‰ phá»¥ thuá»™c Îµ, khÃ´ng phá»¥ thuá»™c x.

Trá»±c giÃ¡c: â€œUniform controlâ€â€”same Î´ works everywhere.

Theorem:
Uniformly continuous â‡’ continuous.

Proof: Trivial (take Î´ uniform). âœ“

Converse sai: Continuous â‡ uniformly continuous.

Example 1: f(x) = xÂ² trÃªn â„

Claim: f continuous nhÆ°ng khÃ´ng uniformly continuous.

Proof:
Cho Îµ = 1.
Suppose âˆƒÎ´ works uniformly.
Chá»n x = 1/Î´, xâ€™ = x + Î´/2.
Then |x - xâ€™| = Î´/2 < Î´, nhÆ°ng: \(|f(x') - f(x)| = |(x + \delta/2)^2 - x^2| = |x\delta + (\delta/2)^2| \approx x\delta = 1/\delta \cdot \delta = 1\) (Vá»›i x lá»›n, expression > 1.) Contradiction! âœ“

Lesson: Unbounded derivative â‡’ khÃ´ng uniformly continuous.

Example 2: f(x) = 1/x trÃªn (0,1)

Claim: f continuous nhÆ°ng khÃ´ng uniformly continuous.

Proof:
xâ‚™ = 1/n, xâ€™â‚™ = 1/(n+1).
|xâ‚™ - xâ€™â‚™| = 1/n - 1/(n+1) = 1/(n(n+1)) â†’ 0.
NhÆ°ng |f(xâ‚™) - f(xâ€™â‚™)| = |n - (n+1)| = 1 â‰  0.
Váº­y khÃ´ng uniformly continuous. âœ“

Lesson: Unbounded function trÃªn bounded domain cÃ³ thá»ƒ fail.

2. Uniform Continuity trÃªn Compact Spaces

Theorem (Heine-Cantor):
f: K â†’ Y continuous, K compact â‡’ f uniformly continuous.

Proof:
Cho Îµ > 0.
âˆ€x âˆˆ K: âˆƒÎ´â‚“: B(x, Î´â‚“) âŠ† fâ»Â¹(B(f(x), Îµ/2)).
Cover K = â‹ƒ B(x, Î´â‚“/2).
K compact â‡’ finite subcover: xâ‚, â€¦, xâ‚™.
Chá»n Î´ = min{Î´â‚“áµ¢/2}.
âˆ€x, xâ€™ vá»›i d(x, xâ€™) < Î´:
x âˆˆ B(xáµ¢, Î´â‚“áµ¢/2) cho some i.
xâ€™ âˆˆ B(xáµ¢, Î´â‚“áµ¢) (triangle inequality).
Both f(x), f(xâ€™) âˆˆ B(f(xáµ¢), Îµ/2) â‡’ d(f(x), f(xâ€™)) < Îµ. âœ“

Consequence: Continuous functions trÃªn [a,b] uniformly continuous.

Remark: Compactness crucial!

3. Extension Theorem

Theorem (Extension of Uniform Continuous Functions):
f: A â†’ Y uniformly continuous, Y complete, A dense trong X â‡’ f extends uniquely Ä‘áº¿n continuous fÌ„: X â†’ Y.

Proof sketch:
Cho x âˆˆ X. A dense â‡’ âˆƒ sequence aâ‚™ âˆˆ A: aâ‚™ â†’ x.
f uniformly continuous â‡’ f(aâ‚™) Cauchy.
Y complete â‡’ f(aâ‚™) converges.
Define fÌ„(x) = lim f(aâ‚™). (Independent cá»§a choice sequence.)
fÌ„ continuous, extends f. âœ“

Application: Extend functions from â„š to â„.

ğŸ“ Lipschitz Continuity

1. Definition

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Lipschitz Continuous):
f: X â†’ Y Lipschitz continuous vá»›i Lipschitz constant L náº¿u:

\[d_Y(f(x), f(y)) \leq L \cdot d_X(x,y) \quad \forall x, y \in X\]

Trá»±c giÃ¡c: Distance khÃ´ng increase quÃ¡ L láº§n.

Notation: f is L-Lipschitz.

Theorem:
Lipschitz â‡’ uniformly continuous â‡’ continuous.

Proof:
Cho Îµ > 0. Chá»n Î´ = Îµ/L.
d_X(x,y) < Î´ â‡’ d_Y(f(x), f(y)) â‰¤ LÂ·d_X(x,y) < LÂ·Î´ = Îµ. âœ“

Converse sai: Uniformly continuous â‡ Lipschitz.

Example: f(x) = âˆšx trÃªn [0,1] uniformly continuous (compact), nhÆ°ng khÃ´ng Lipschitz (derivative unbounded táº¡i 0).

2. Examples

Example 1: f(x) = 3x + 5 trÃªn â„.
|f(x) - f(y)| = 3|x - y|. Lipschitz vá»›i L = 3. âœ“

Example 2: f(x) = sin(x) trÃªn â„.
|sin(x) - sin(y)| â‰¤ |x - y| (mean value theorem). Lipschitz vá»›i L = 1. âœ“

Example 3: f(x) = xÂ² trÃªn [0, M].
|f(x) - f(y)| = |x - y| Â· |x + y| â‰¤ 2M |x - y|. Lipschitz vá»›i L = 2M. âœ“
(NhÆ°ng trÃªn â„ unbounded, khÃ´ng Lipschitz.)

3. Contraction Mappings

Äá»‹nh nghÄ©a (Contraction):
f: X â†’ X lÃ  contraction (hay contraction mapping) náº¿u âˆƒ k < 1:

\[d(f(x), f(y)) \leq k \cdot d(x,y) \quad \forall x,y\]

NÃ³i báº±ng lá»i: Lipschitz vá»›i constant k < 1.

Trá»±c giÃ¡c: f â€œcontractsâ€ distancesâ€”Ä‘iá»ƒm closer sau apply f.

Theorem (Banach Fixed Point Theorem):
Cho (X, d) complete metric space, f: X â†’ X contraction.
ThÃ¬ âˆƒ! x* âˆˆ X: f(x) = x (fixed point).

Moreover: âˆ€xâ‚€ âˆˆ X, sequence xâ‚™â‚Šâ‚ = f(xâ‚™) converges to x*.

Proof:

Step 1 (Construct sequence):
Chá»n xâ‚€ arbitrary. Define xâ‚™â‚Šâ‚ = f(xâ‚™).

Step 2 (Cauchy):
d(xâ‚™â‚Šâ‚, xâ‚™) = d(f(xâ‚™), f(xâ‚™â‚‹â‚)) â‰¤ kÂ·d(xâ‚™, xâ‚™â‚‹â‚) â‰¤ â€¦ â‰¤ kâ¿Â·d(xâ‚, xâ‚€).

Vá»›i m > n: \(d(x_m, x_n) \leq d(x_m, x_{m-1}) + \cdots + d(x_{n+1}, x_n) \leq (k^{m-1} + \cdots + k^n) d(x_1, x_0)\) \(\leq k^n \frac{1}{1-k} d(x_1, x_0) \to 0\) Váº­y (xâ‚™) Cauchy. âœ“

Step 3 (Converge):
X complete â‡’ xâ‚™ â†’ x* âˆˆ X.

Step 4 (Fixed point):
f(x) = f(lim xâ‚™) = lim f(xâ‚™) = lim xâ‚™â‚Šâ‚ = x. âœ“

Step 5 (Uniqueness):
Suppose f(y) = y.
d(x, y) = d(f(x), f(y)) â‰¤ kÂ·d(x, y).
k < 1 â‡’ d(x, y) = 0 â‡’ x* = y. âœ“ QED

Corollary (Rate of Convergence):

\[d(x_n, x^*) \leq \frac{k^n}{1-k} d(x_1, x_0)\]

Remark: Exponential convergence!

Application: Solving Equations

Problem: Solve g(x) = 0.

Rewrite: x = x - g(x) = f(x).

If f contraction trÃªn complete space, âˆƒ! solution.

Example: Solve x = cos(x).
f(x) = cos(x) contraction trÃªn [0,1]?
|fâ€™(x)| = |sin(x)| â‰¤ sin(1) < 1 âœ“
Váº­y unique fixed point x* â‰ˆ 0.739. âœ“

ğŸ§© Exercises

Equivalent Metrics

  1. Verify Equivalence:
    Chá»©ng minh chi tiáº¿t dâ‚, dâ‚‚, dâˆ equivalent trÃªn â„Â².

  2. Not Equivalent:
    d_disc vÃ  d_Euclidean khÃ´ng equivalent trÃªn â„. Chá»©ng minh báº±ng explicit open set.

  3. Strongly Equivalent:
    d(x,y) vÃ  2d(x,y) strongly equivalent? Verify.

Uniform Continuity

  1. Compute:
    f(x) = xÂ³ uniformly continuous trÃªn [-1, 1]? TrÃªn â„?

  2. Heine-Cantor:
    Ãp dá»¥ng Heine-Cantor: f(x) = 1/x continuous trÃªn [1,2] â‡’ uniformly continuous.

  3. Counterexample:
    TÃ¬m f continuous trÃªn (0,1) nhÆ°ng khÃ´ng uniformly continuous.

Lipschitz

  1. Verify Lipschitz:
    f(x) = |x| Lipschitz trÃªn â„ vá»›i L = 1.

  2. Not Lipschitz:
    f(x) = xÂ² khÃ´ng Lipschitz trÃªn â„. Prove.

  3. Bounded Derivative:
    f: [a,b] â†’ â„ differentiable, |fâ€™| â‰¤ M â‡’ f Lipschitz vá»›i L = M.

Banach Fixed Point

  1. Apply Banach:
    f(x) = (x + 2)/3 contraction trÃªn â„. Find fixed point.

  2. Solve Equation:
    x = e^(-x) has unique solution. Use Banach Fixed Point.

  3. Rate of Convergence:
    Trong bÃ i 11, xâ‚€ = 0. Compute xâ‚, xâ‚‚, xâ‚ƒ. Estimate x*.

    Sketch proof convergence using Banach.

  3. Fractal:
    Sierpinski triangle defined by contraction mappings. Describe.

Advanced

  1. Extension Theorem:
    f: â„š âˆ© [0,1] â†’ â„, f(x) = xÂ². Extend to [0,1].

  2. Kakutani:
    Research Kakutani Fixed Point Theorem (set-valued maps).

  3. Brouwer:
    Brouwer Fixed Point Theorem (continuous f: Dâ¿ â†’ Dâ¿ has fixed point).
    Relation vá»›i Banach?

Reflection

  1. Why Completeness?:
    Banach Fixed Point requires completeness. Example contraction trÃªn incomplete space without fixed point?

  2. Applications:
    List 3 applications cá»§a Banach Fixed Point Theorem trong different fields.
